image.altText: a woman holds the back of a toddler who is pushing a stroller along a footpath

props.synopsis: There are about 120 children and young people living in arrangements designed to be short-term but often result in stays of more than a year, with supervision provided by unaccredited labour hire staff.

title.children: 'Get kids out of hotels': Children caught up in foster care crisis to give evidence at NSW inquiry

image.altText: Cameras filming a pro-Voice press conference

props.synopsis: More than 50 Victorian and national health organisations say the Voice will positively impact health outcomes for First Nations people.

title.children: Health organisations across the country pledge their support for the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A man on a motorbike is surrounded by bushfire.

props.synopsis: The Emergency Management Minister tells Insiders authorities are better prepared for this summer compared to the months leading up to the Black Summer fires in 2019 and 2020.

title.children: Minister says Australia 'much better prepared' for bushfire threat this summer

image.altText: A close up image of a mechanical wristwatch being worked on by someone wearing purple gloves under a light

props.synopsis: As the US prepares to spend $1.16 trillion revamping its nuclear defences, a rare glimpse inside the country's missile bases reveals many maintenance tasks are still done by hand.

title.children: The delicate art of maintaining the United States' ageing nuclear weapons

image.altText: A computer screen with the scamwatch webpage open on it.

props.synopsis: Scams are everywhere. So how do you protect yourselves? We asked experts from banks, police, telcos and fraud agencies. Here's what they recommend.

title.children: Here are the top tips from experts to protect yourself against scams

image.altText: a woman taking a selfie while standing on sand at a beach

props.synopsis: NSW Police suspend the use of bean-bag rounds, part of their arsenal for the past 10 years, after the death of Krista Kach. What exactly is the device also known as a super-sock round?

title.children: What are bean-bag rounds, the police weaponry that killed NSW woman Krista last week?

image.altText: A dark grey Toyota Rav4 from behind.

props.synopsis: A search of the vehicle revealed cocaine in two motorised hidden compartments, which ACT Policing say were sophisticated and professionally installed, indicative of organised crime.

title.children: Cocaine worth $280,000 found in hidden compartments of repossessed car in Canberra

image.altText: Jack Ziebell

props.synopsis: Former North Melbourne skipper Jack Ziebell says he is still feeling the impact of an alleged assault outside a Melbourne bar on the night of his retirement, with more surgery on the horizon.

title.children: 'I'm lucky I'm here': Retired North champ Ziebell says he will need more surgery after alleged assault outside bar

image.altText: An F1 driver, out of the car, wearing a black shirt and orange cap, being talked to by a man with earmuffs

props.synopsis: Australian rookie Oscar Piastri has secured his first podium in Formula 1, finishing third at Sunday's Japanese Grand Prix.

title.children: Piastri achieves first F1 podium at Japanese Grand Prix

image.altText: A woman pushes Natasha Fyles with one hand and pushes a paper plate into her face with the other hand

props.synopsis: NT Police have confirmed they are investigating the incident, which occurred at Nightcliff Markets about 11.40am on Sunday morning.

title.children: 'Disgusting': Police investigating after NT Chief Minister allegedly attacked with pancake

image.altText: A picture of Hardeep Singh Nijjar wearing a yellow turban and black jacket on a yellow banner.

props.synopsis: Hardeep Singh Nijjar had been warned his life was in danger. But when he walked out of his Sikh temple in Canada, he had no idea two assassins were lying in wait.

title.children: How a brazen assassination confirmed a community's fears and decimated Canada-India relations

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch sitting on a couch with a young boy and a blonde woman

props.synopsis: Lachlan Murdoch was once the reluctant heir apparent to a sprawling media empire, spending years in the wilderness after a confrontation with his father. This is how he was welcomed back into the fold and handed the keys to the kingdom.

title.children: To claim the throne, Lachlan Murdoch gave up his independence and his relationship with his brother

image.altText: An artists impression of the capsule reentering Earth's atmosphere

props.synopsis: A capsule carrying a 4.5 billion-year-old piece of asteroid will come crashing down to Earth on Monday, and nine Australians will have the chance to observe it firsthand.

title.children: A NASA mission is set to return to Earth and Australian scientists will have a front-row seat

image.altText: A man bends down to pick up a piece of coal at Collie Western Australia Griffin Coal Mine.

props.synopsis: Once a source of pride and prosperity, a foreign-owned Australian coal mine is now a byword for debt and despair. Observers say it's also a time bomb that's set to explode on energy users.

title.children: Trashed fortunes and favour lost: Inside the 'madness' of a state's energy woes

image.altText: A composite image showing an old mental institution and a photo of a young woman against a pink background.

props.synopsis: Alison Watts's grandmother was diagnosed with "puerperal insanity" and institutionalised not long after giving birth to her father. He didn't meet her — or know she was alive — until his early 20s.

title.children: My grandmother Ada spent her life inside mental institutions. I tried to untangle why

image.altText: Chloe Molloy

props.synopsis: Chloe Molloy and Emma Swanson both put their names in the hat for goal of the nominations in a scrappy battle in Sydney. Get the full wrap of the AFLW here.

title.children: Captains Molloy and Swanson provide goal of the year highlights as the Swans see off the Eagles

image.altText: An NRLW player in blue falling backwards in a tackle with the ball, as two opponents grapple her

props.synopsis: The Newcastle Knights will take on the Gold Coast Titans in next Sunday's NRLW grand final — check out all the stats and news here.

title.children: Knights and Titans to face-off in NRLW grand final after stirring victories of the Broncos and Roosters

image.altText: An older, bespectacled woman with dyed hair stands amid packing boxes in a kitchen.

props.synopsis: Lesley Scott-Smith used to be the one helping families going through tough times, but now she needs access to the services she once referred others to.

title.children: 70-year-old advocate for families in need forced to move house for sixth time in nine years

image.altText: an image of rugby league players training

props.synopsis: Nestled in NSW's rugby league heartland, the Maitland Pickers again defend a trophy only they've ever won.

title.children: Inside the rugby league town that's produced dozens of the game's greats

image.altText: Caprice Sobel with daughter Isobel and husband Clinton Parker

props.synopsis: Clinton Parker's melanoma is unrelated to sunlight exposure. He's been given just 12 to 24 months to live.

title.children: Clinton's big toe wouldn't heal. By the time he was diagnosed with a rare melanoma, it was too late

image.altText: A woman stands smiling.

props.synopsis: Sandra Sully says she once called out the behaviour of a former male colleague after hearing him say a particular journalist's breasts were too large for her role on camera.

title.children: Sandra Sully says the emphasis on her appearance has been 'ridiculous' during her television career

image.altText: A grand old building in a country town.

props.synopsis: The New South Wales government has endorsed the Trades Hall in Broken Hill for inclusion on the UNESCO World Heritage Tentative List.

title.children: Historic building in outback city endorsed for World Heritage listing

image.altText: A colourful subdivision plan of Narara from 1924

props.synopsis: The State Library of NSW has digitised subdivision plans from as far back as the 1880s and they're not just advertisements. They're works of art.

title.children: Travel back to a time when there was a 'romantic' excitement about new suburbs

image.altText: Pat Cummins throws his son into the air

props.synopsis: At least 14 children travelled with the Australian men's Test side during the recent Ashes series. Here's how the players' young families helped keep them grounded through such a gruelling and dramatic tour.

title.children: The image that sums up the changing dynamic of the Australian men's Test cricket team

image.altText: The sun shines through the clouds over sn open green field of rice crops.

props.synopsis: Rice is agriculture's second-largest methane emitter, surpassing beef, but a small group of growers is producing a rain-fed crop, with a smaller environmental footprint. The problem is they can't export it.

title.children: Farmers want to export 'climate-smart' rice — but an old law stands in their way

image.altText: Castle Bravo nuclear test

props.synopsis: For some, the name "Bikini Bottom" will be synonymous with a pineapple under the sea — the fictional home of SpongeBob SquarePants. But the underwater world of the quirky cartoon character is based on a real place in the Pacific Ocean — and one with a dark history.

title.children: Nuclear bombs vaporised parts of the Bikini Atoll decades ago. What are the lasting impacts today?

image.altText: A man wearing a black jumper smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Luke Thomson was known as a confident and outgoing footy coach, so his mates were surprised when he was diagnosed with anxiety and depression.

title.children: Luke hid behind his 'confident' guy persona for years. Then, the dam wall burst

image.altText: Camille Bianchi sits listening to someone speaking off camera.

props.synopsis: That a paedophile had worked on a children's hospital ward for almost two decades was Launceston's worst kept secret. Then one phone call changed everything, setting in motion a series of events that would alter Tasmania forever.

title.children: It took a call between two old housemates to expose a paedophile and change a state forever

image.altText: Close up of a man's face in front of a statue of Mary and Jesus

props.synopsis: He still has a beer named after him at a local pub but few people are toasting the career of Bishop Christopher Saunders. It's been a rapid fall from grace for the senior cleric who's accused of sexual assault and appears to be disobeying Vatican orders.

title.children: The Vatican has lost control of Australian Bishop Christopher Saunders. Here's how it happened.

image.altText: A beekeeper couple standing in amongst bee hives.

props.synopsis: The transition from beehive eradication to management of varroa mite comes as a relief for Kempsey beekeepers who no longer have to euthanase their hives.

title.children: Beehive eradication nearly saw the Costas lose their livelihoods, but this week's decision spares them

image.altText: A photo of AIsha wearing hijab, in a floral dress, and wearing sunglasses over her scarf.

props.synopsis: For those who follow Islam, wearing a hijab is prescribed for women from puberty. But some women have complicated relationships with the head covering.

title.children: Aisha used to get called 'Osama bin Laden's wife'. She shares what it's like to wear a face covering in Australia

image.altText: Thao Tran looking at the camera with tattoos.

props.synopsis: In most Asian cultures, tattoos are viewed as a symbol of gang activity, violence or criminal behaviour. As a result, many children choose to hide their tattoos to avoid conflict with their parents.

title.children: Thao Tran's mum told her that if she ever got a tattoo, she would scrape it off her
